title: Md Khalid Bin Kamal
text:
PhD Student — Public Policy & Political Economy
University of Texas at Dallas
CV | Google Scholar | khalid@utdallas.edu

I study how institutions, policies, and political shocks shape economic outcomes, particularly in developing contexts. My research applies causal inference methods to evaluate real-world policy interventions in governance, labor markets, and welfare systems.




Article on secession and food prices published in Agricultural and Food Economics (2025)

Paper on Yemen food price inflation accepted in Humanities and Social Sciences Communications (2025)

title: About
text:
Public service has shaped my life from an early age. As a third-generation public servant from Bangladesh and now a Joint Director at Bangladesh Bank, I have spent over a decade working on development policy and financial sector programs. In that role, I witnessed how carefully designed policies can improve livelihoods—and how poorly designed ones can unintentionally restrict opportunity. Those experiences led me to pursue doctoral research in Public Policy and Political Economy at the University of Texas at Dallas.
My research focuses on how institutions, governance structures, and policy design influence economic outcomes, particularly in developing and politically complex environments. I use empirical methods and causal inference approaches to study how public policies affect real-world welfare and development trajectories.
I aim to produce scholarship that bridges rigorous academic analysis with practical policy relevance, contributing to institutional design and public policy reforms that promote equitable and sustainable development.

title: Research
text:
Current Projects

Wrongful Discharge Laws & Employee Productivity
Core question:
Do employment protection doctrines improve or reduce firm productivity?
What I am doing:
This project estimates the causal impact of wrongful discharge laws on firm-level productivity outcomes using panel data on U.S. public firms. The study evaluates competing theoretical predictions about employment protection and labor market efficiency.
Methods: Difference-in-Differences, fixed effects panel models, entropy balancing robustness checks.
Keywords: labor regulation, employment protection, productivity, causal inference, labor economics.
Status: Paper prepared for conference presentation (MPSA 2026, Chicago).



Employer-Sponsored Childcare & Employee Retention
Core question:
Does access to employer-provided childcare reduce employee turnover?
What I am doing:
This project examines the causal effect of workplace childcare provision on employee retention using quasi-experimental policy thresholds that generate exogenous variation in eligibility.
Methods: Fuzzy Regression Discontinuity Design, local treatment effects estimation.
Keywords: labor markets, gender economics, workplace policy, retention, causal inference.
Status: Accepted for presentation at the Western Social Science Association Conference (2026, U.S.).



Shelby County v. Holder and Fiscal Equity
Core question:
How did the removal of federal preclearance requirements affect distributive policy outcomes?
What I am doing:
This study evaluates whether the 2013 Supreme Court decision altered state-level public spending patterns, focusing on education, healthcare, and welfare allocations.
Methods: Difference-in-Differences, event-study models, state-year panel analysis.
Keywords: voting rights, federalism, redistribution, public finance, institutional change.



Reducing Waste of Scarce Clinical Resources: AI Prediction of Patient No-Shows
Core question:
Can predictive analytics improve healthcare resource allocation efficiency?
What I am doing:
This project analyzes whether statistical prediction of appointment no-shows can reduce wasted clinical resources and improve scheduling efficiency. The study treats missed appointments as an economic allocation problem rather than purely behavioral non-compliance.
Methods: Logistic prediction models, simulation of targeted interventions, cost-benefit analysis.
Keywords: health economics, predictive analytics, resource allocation, applied microeconomics.
Status: Ongoing project (2026).



Impact of E-Wallet Usage on Cashless Purchase Decisions
Core question:
Does digital wallet adoption causally increase cashless spending behavior?
What I am doing:
This project evaluates the causal effect of mobile e-wallet usage on digital purchasing behavior using a randomized encouragement field experiment conducted in Khulna, Bangladesh. Individuals randomly offered assistance installing a payment app are compared to a control group to identify behavioral changes attributable to adoption.
Methods: Randomized Encouragement Design, instrumental variables estimation, two-stage least squares.
Keywords: digital finance, financial inclusion, technology adoption, field experiments.
Status: Working paper.

title: Research
text:
Working Papers & Preprints
Impact of E-Wallet App Usage on Cashless Purchase Decision: Evidence from Field Experiment
Field experiment on digital payments showing that increased e-wallet usage significantly raises cashless purchases, particularly for non-food items, while leaving food purchases unaffected. :contentReferenceoaicite:0
In the Blast Radius: The Effect of Airstrikes on Household Food Security and Dietary Diversity in Gaza
Joint work examining the impact of conflict exposure on food security outcomes using household-level data.
The Impact of Employer-Sponsored Childcare Facilities on Employee Retention: A Fuzzy Regression Discontinuity Approach
Quasi-experimental study estimating retention effects of workplace childcare provision.

title: Research
text:

From Revolution to Inflation: The Economic Consequences of the Arab Spring on Yemen’s Food Prices
Humanities and Social Sciences Communications (2025)
Empirical study linking political instability to food inflation dynamics.
Impact of Water Supply Disruption on Food Insecurity Experience: Evidence from Kyrgyz Farming Households

Household-level analysis of infrastructure shocks and food insecurity.
